Sentence: I Joseph I was born in Gary, Indiana, near Chicago, on August 29, 1958. I was the eighth of ten children in the I family, a working-class African-American family living in a two-bedroom house on I Street.

Boy", was released in 1968. Bobby Taylor of Bobby Taylor & the Vancouvers brought the I 5 to Motown after they opened for Taylor at Chicago's Regal Theater in 1968. In 1969, Motown executives decided Diana Ross should introduce the I 5 to the public—partly to bolster her career in television—sending off what was considered Motown's last product of its "production line".

The I 5 made their first television appearance in 1969 in the Miss Black America pageant, performing a cover of "It's Your Thing". Rolling Stone later described the young I as "a prodigy" with "overwhelming musical gifts" who "quickly emerged as the main draw and lead singer".In January 1970,

According to music journalist Joseph Vogel, the demeaning name first appeared in British tabloid The Sun in 1985. The name's origins come from Jacko Macacco, the name of a famous monkey used in monkey-baiting matches at the Westminster Pit in the early 1820s. "Jacko" was used in Cockney slang to refer to monkeys in general, hence a racist connotation behind the name.In 1987, Rolling Stone described I as "the flighty-genius star-child, a celebrity virtually all my life, who dwells in a fairy-tale kingdom of fellow celebrities, animals, mannequins and cartoons, who provides endless fodder for the tabloids....

Sega Technical Institute director Roger Hector and Sonic the Hedgehog co-creator Naoto Ohshima said that my involvement was terminated and my music reworked following the allegations. However, my musical director Brad Buxer and two other members of my team, Doug Grigsby III and Ciorocco Jones, said the music remained and that I went uncredited because I was unhappy with how the Genesis replicated my music.Beginning in May 2002, a documentary film crew led by Martin Bashir followed I for several months. The documentary, broadcast in February 2003 as Living with I Jackson, showed I holding hands and discussing sleeping arrangements with a 12-year-old boy.

In a June 28, 2009 Baltimore Sun article, Jill Rosen wrote that my legacy influenced fields including sound, dance, fashion, music videos and celebrity.Pop critic Robert Christgau wrote that my work from the 1970s to the early 1990s showed "immense originality, adaptability, and ambition" with "genius beats, hooks, arrangements, and vocals (though not lyrics)", music that "will stand forever as a reproach to the puritanical notion that pop music is slick or shallow and that's the end of it". During the 1990s, as I lost control of my "troubling life", my music suffered and began to shape "an arc not merely of promise fulfilled and outlived, but of something approaching tragedy: a phenomenally ebullient child star tops himself like none before, only to transmute audibly into a lost weirdo".
